clinical_study.brief_title: Endonasal Dacryocystorhinostomy and Evolution of the Stoma Size
clinical_study.official_title: Endonasal Dacryocystorhinostomy: Prospective Study of the Evolution of the Stoma Size

brief_summary.textblock:
Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is a procedure of choice for nasolacrimal duct obstruction. Endonasal procedures for DCR were described as early as 1893 by Caldwell. However, external DCR was practiced more commonly because of better visualization of anatomic features. The miniaturization of surgical instruments and close partnership between ophthalmologist and otorhinolaryngologist had led to a renewal of endonasal approach.
The main objective of the study is to show the evolution of stoma size after endonasal DCR and validate the direct measurement of mucous orifice. It will also allow determining if the stoma evolution size may be a predictive factor for operational effectiveness.

primary_outcome.description: Measurement of the stoma size by endonasal photography

secondary_outcome.description: Measurement of the osteotomy orifices size from photography

secondary_outcome.measure: Ratio of patients for whom the operation is a success
secondary_outcome.description: A success corresponds to the complete disappearance of epiphora symptomatology, on the contrary, a failure equals to the persistence of tearing or a recurrence of dacryocystitis

study_pop.textblock: Patients who had chronic epiphora or chronic dacryocystitis.
